{{taxobox | image = Tiny_Russula_paludosa_(Appelrussula)_at_Rozendaal_castle_park_-_panoramio.jpg | image_caption = | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Russulales]] | familia = [[Russulaceae]] | genus = ''[[Russula]]'' | species = '''''R. paludosa''''' | binomial = ''Russula paludosa'' | binomial_authority = Britzelm. (1891) | synonyms = ''R. elatior'' Lindbl. (1901)
''R. fragaria'' [[Otakar Kudrna|Kudrna]] (1919)
''[[Russula integra|R. integra]]'' var. ''paludosa'' (Britzelm.) [[Rolf Singer|Singer]] (1923)
''[[Russula integra|R. integra]]'' var. ''rubrotincta'' [[Charles Horton Peck|Peck]] (1902)
''R. olgae'' [[Josef Velenovský|Velen.]] (1920) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = Russula paludosa | whichGills = decurrent | capShape = convex | hymeniumType = gills | stipeCharacter = bare | ecologicalType = mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor = ochre | sporePrintColor2 = | howEdible = edible }} '''''Russula paludosa''''' is an edible species of [[fungus|mushroom]] within the large genus ''[[Russula]]''. It is common to Europe and North America. ==Description== The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is convex to depressed and is coloured a distinctive bloody red, pink, crimson or purple. Sometimes it may show a yellowish or orange tinge in the centre. It may measure between 6 and 20 cm in diameter. The [[Trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white with a mild taste and without scent; it quickly becomes soft and spongy and also greyish. The crowded [[Gill (mycology)|gills]] are cream coloured when young, and become yellow with age. They are adnexed and are generally thin. Their edges may sometimes occur reddish. The [[Amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]], elli [[spore]]s measure 8–10 by 7–10 [[Micrometer|μm]] are warty and are covered by an incomplete mesh. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is white, sometimes with a pink hue, slightly clubbed. It may measure 5 to 15 cm in height and up to 3 cm in diameter. ==Distribution, ecology and habitat== ''R. paludosa'' is [[mycorrhizal]] and occurs in [[coniferous forest|coniferous woodland]]s and in peat bogs of Europe and North America; preferably under [[pine]] trees, where it forms mycorrhizae. Locally it can be very common. ==Edibility== The mushroom is edible and is a common good in [[Finland|Finnish]] markets.Pegler. Yet it may easily be mistaken for ''[[Russula emetica]]'', which is poisonous. ==See also== *[[List of Russula species|List of ''Russula'' species]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite book|title=The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North Western Europe |last= Bon |first=Marcel |authorlink= Marcel Bon |year=1987 | publisher= Hodder and Stoughton |isbn = 0-340-39935-X}} *{{cite book|title=Pocket Guide to Mushrooms and Toadstools | first=David N. |last=Pegler |year=1981 |page=26 |publisher=Mitchell Beazley Publishers |location=London |isbn=978-0-85533-366-9}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.commanster.eu/commanster/Mushrooms/Russula/SuRussula/Russula.paludosa.html |title=Russula paludosa |first=J.K. |last=Lindsey | work=Ecology of Commanster}} *{{cite book|first=Edmund |last= Garnweidner | title=Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and Europe | publisher= Collins |year= 1994 |isbn=978-0-261-67406-6}} ==External links== {{IndexFungorum|206457}}
